keywords.long_help: The 'var' keyword is used to declare a new variable. Variables can hold values of any data type including strings, numbers, booleans, JSON objects, and arrays. You can optionally specify the data type using the syntax 'var name:type = value;' (e.g., var x:int=10;).
The 'print' keyword outputs the given value or expression to the console. It automatically converts values to strings for display.
The 'call' keyword is used to invoke builtin functions. It can be used as a statement or within expressions to execute system-provided functionality.
keywords.example:
var content = call file.readTextFile(path="data.txt");
call debug.log(message="Processing started");

keywords.short_description: Returns a value from a block
keywords.long_help: The 'return' keyword exits the current execution block and optionally returns a value. It's commonly used in functions and conditional blocks.
The 'if' keyword begins a conditional statement that executes code based on a boolean condition. Must be followed by 'then' and optionally 'else'.
The 'then' keyword follows an 'if' condition and introduces the block of code to execute when the condition is true.
The 'else' keyword provides an alternative execution path when the 'if' condition evaluates to false.
The 'foreach' keyword creates a loop that iterates over each element in a collection (array or JSON array). Must be used with 'in'.
The 'in' keyword is used in 'foreach' loops to specify the collection to iterate over.
The 'while' keyword creates a loop that continues executing as long as the specified condition remains true. Must be followed by 'do'.
The 'do' keyword introduces the body of a 'while' or 'foreach' loop, marking the start of the code block to be executed repeatedly.
The 'break' keyword (also 'exit') immediately exits the current loop, continuing execution after the loop block.
The 'continue' keyword skips the remaining code in the current loop iteration and proceeds to the next iteration.
The 'connect' keyword creates a new database connection using a JDBC connection string. Supports Oracle, MySQL, and PostgreSQL.
keywords.example:
connect db = "jdbc:oracle:thin:@//host:1521/service";
connect mysqlDb = "jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/mydb";

keywords.long_help: The 'use' keyword creates a context block for database operations, automatically managing connection resources.
The 'cursor' keyword declares a database cursor for iterating through query results. Cursors must be opened, used, and then closed.
The 'open' keyword executes a cursor query with optional bind parameters, preparing it for iteration.
keywords.example: open c(id: 123, status: "active");

keywords.long_help: The 'close' keyword releases resources associated with a cursor or database connection.
keywords.example:
close c;
close connection db;

keywords.long_help: The 'connection' keyword is used with 'close' to explicitly close a database connection.
keywords.example: close connection db;

keywords.long_help: The 'select' keyword begins a SQL query to retrieve data from database tables.
keywords.example: cursor c = select * from users where age > 18;

keywords.long_help: The 'from' keyword in SQL queries specifies which table or tables to query data from.
keywords.example: select name, email from customers;

keywords.long_help: The 'where' keyword in SQL queries specifies conditions for filtering results.
keywords.example: select * from orders where status = 'pending';

keywords.long_help: The 'order' keyword in SQL queries sorts the results. Must be followed by 'by' and column name(s).
keywords.example: select * from products order by price;

keywords.long_help: The 'by' keyword follows 'order' or 'group' in SQL queries to specify the column(s) to use.
keywords.example: select * from items order by created_date by desc;

keywords.long_help: The 'group' keyword in SQL queries groups rows that have the same values in specified columns.
keywords.example: select department, count(*) from employees group by department;

keywords.long_help: The 'having' keyword filters results after grouping, similar to 'where' but for aggregated data.
keywords.example: select dept, count(*) from emp group by dept having count(*) > 5;

keywords.long_help: The 'screen' keyword creates a new JavaFX window (Stage) with properties specified in JSON format. Supports title, width, height, maximize, vars, and area properties. Variables can have display metadata with input types: textfield, textarea, passwordfield, checkbox, radiobutton, togglebutton, combobox, choicebox, listview, spinner, slider, datepicker, colorpicker, button, label, hyperlink, imageview, mediaview, webview, progressbar, progressindicator. Areas support container types: pane, stackpane, anchorpane, borderpane, flowpane, gridpane, hbox, vbox, tilepane, scrollpane, splitpane, tabpane, tab, accordion, titledpane, group, region, canvas. All types have default styling.
keywords.example: screen myWindow = {title:"My App", width:800, height:600, vars:[{name:"userName", type:"string", default:"", display:{type:"textfield", mandatory:true}}], area:[{name:"mainArea", type:"vbox", layout:"vbox", items:[{name:"userField", sequence:1, relativePos:"top", varRef:"userName"}]}]};

keywords.long_help: The 'null' keyword represents the absence of a value or an uninitialized variable.
The 'true' keyword represents the boolean true value.
The 'false' keyword represents the boolean false value.

builtins.long_help:
Reads the entire contents of a text file and returns it as a string. The file must be in a safe directory or the
script's own directory.

Writes the given text content to a file. Creates the file if it doesn't exist, overwrites if it does. The file must be
in a safe directory.
Returns true if the specified file or directory exists, false otherwise.
Returns a JSON array containing the names of files and subdirectories in the specified directory.
Converts any value to its string representation.
Returns a new string with all characters converted to uppercase.
Returns a new string with all characters converted to lowercase.
Returns a new string with leading and trailing whitespace removed.
Returns a new string with all occurrences of the target substring replaced with the replacement string.
Splits a string into an array of substrings using the specified regex pattern as the delimiter. Returns a JSON array.
Concatenates all elements of a JSON array into a single string, separated by the specified delimiter.
Returns true if the string contains the specified substring, false otherwise.

builtins.short_description: Checks if string starts with prefix
builtins.long_help: Returns true if the string starts with the specified prefix, false otherwise.

builtins.short_description: Checks if string ends with suffix
builtins.long_help: Returns true if the string ends with the specified suffix, false otherwise.
Parses a JSON-formatted string and returns it as a JSON object (Map or List).
Retrieves a value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns null if the path doesn't exist.

Retrieves a string value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns a default value if the path doesn't
exist.

Retrieves an integer value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns a default value if the path doesn't
exist.

Retrieves a boolean value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns a default value if the path doesn't
exist.

Sets a value at the specified path in a JSON object. Creates intermediate objects as needed. Returns the modified JSON
object.
Removes the value at the specified path from a JSON object. Returns the modified JSON object.
Returns true if the JSON object or array is empty (no properties or elements), false otherwise.

Registers a JSON schema with a given name for later validation. The schema defines the expected structure, types, and
constraints for JSON data.

Analyzes a JSON object and generates a schema that describes its structure. Optionally calculates length constraints for
strings and arrays.

Validates a JSON object against a registered schema. Returns a list of validation errors, or an empty list if validation
succeeds.
Sorts the elements of the array in place. For ascending order, use ascending=true.
Outputs a debug message to the debug console if debugging is enabled.
Enables debug mode, causing debug.log messages to be output.
Disables debug mode, suppressing debug.log messages.
Throws an error if the specified condition is false. Used for debugging and testing.
Returns a JSON object containing all currently defined variables and their values.

Executes an HTTP GET request to the specified URL. Returns a JSON envelope containing status, headers, and body.
Optional headers can be provided as a JSON object. Timeout is in milliseconds.

Executes an HTTP POST request with optional body content. Returns a JSON envelope with status, headers, and body.
Headers are optional JSON object. Body is sent as-is.

Performs HTTP GET and automatically parses the response body as JSON. Throws an error if response is not valid JSON.
Returns the parsed JSON directly (not wrapped in envelope).

Performs HTTP POST with JSON body and parses the JSON response. Automatically serializes the jsonBody parameter and sets
Content-Type header. Returns parsed JSON response.
Performs HTTP GET and returns the response body as a plain string. Useful for fetching HTML, XML, or plain text content.

Performs HTTP POST with text body and returns response as plain string. The body parameter is sent as-is without JSON
serialization.

Checks if an HTTP response has a 2xx status code. Accepts either a full response envelope or just a status code. Throws
an error with optional message if status is not 2xx.

Calls an OpenAI-compatible API to generate text completions. Supports optional system prompt, required user prompt, and
optional maxTokens and temperature parameters. Uses configuration from system properties or environment variables.
builtins.example:
var answer = call ai.complete(system="You are a helpful assistant", user="Explain quantum
computing", maxTokens=500, temperature=0.7);
print answer;

builtins.long_help: Uses AI to generate a concise summary of the provided text. Optionally specify maximum tokens for the summary length.

Generates vector embeddings for the given text using an AI embedding model. Returns a JSON array of floating-point
numbers representing the semantic meaning of the text. Useful for similarity searches and semantic analysis.

Uses AI to classify the given text into one of the provided labels. The labels parameter should be a JSON array of
strings. Returns the most appropriate label.

Calls an OpenAI-compatible API asynchronously in a background thread. The callback function is invoked when the call
completes, receiving a JSON object with: success (bool), result (string), error (string). This allows the UI to remain
responsive during long-running AI operations.
builtins.example:
call ai.completeAsync(system="You are a helpful assistant", user="Explain quantum computing",
maxTokens=500, temperature=0.7, callback="onAiComplete");

// Callback function definition
onAiComplete(response: json) {
if call json.getBool(response, "success", false) then {
var result: string = call json.getString(response, "result", "");
print result;
} else {
print "Error: " + call json.getString(response, "error", "Unknown error");
}
}

builtins.short_description: Decodes a base64 string to a byte array
builtins.long_help:
Decodes a base64-encoded string and returns the decoded bytes as an array. Useful for handling binary data encoded in
text format.

builtins.short_description: Encodes a byte array to base64 string
builtins.long_help: Encodes a byte array to a base64-encoded string. Useful for converting binary data to a text-safe format.
Expands an array to the specified length. If the array is smaller, null elements are added. Modifies the array in place.

Fills an array to the specified length with the given value. If value is not provided, fills with null. Modifies the
array in place.

Generates a visual class hierarchy tree from Java source files in the specified directory. If no directory is provided,
uses the current directory.

Scans Java source files in the specified directory and analyzes the class structure. Returns metadata about classes,
interfaces, and their relationships.

Asserts that the expected and actual values are equal. Returns true if equal, false otherwise. Optionally logs a custom
message on failure.

Sets the file path where debug output should be written. Debug messages will be appended to this file instead of console
output.

Returns current memory usage statistics including used, free, and total memory. Unit parameter can be 'B', 'KB', 'MB',
or 'GB'. Default is 'MB'.
Creates a new debug output file, overwriting if it exists. Subsequent debug messages will be written to this file.

Returns the current call stack as a JSON array. Each element contains information about a stack frame including line
numbers and context.
Disables trace mode debugging. Trace mode logs detailed execution information for troubleshooting.

Enables trace mode debugging. Trace mode logs detailed execution information including every statement and expression
evaluated.
builtins.example: call debug.traceOn(); // Detailed execution trace will be logged

builtins.long_help: Closes a file handle that was previously opened with file.open(). Always close files when done to free system resources.

builtins.short_description: Closes an open ZIP file handle
builtins.long_help: Closes a ZIP file handle that was opened with file.openZip(). Ensures all data is flushed and resources are freed.

Copies a file from source path to destination path. Overwrites destination if it exists. Both paths must be within safe
directories.

builtins.short_description: Checks if end of file reached
builtins.long_help:
Checks if the file pointer has reached the end of the file for the given handle. Returns true if at EOF, false
otherwise.
Returns a JSON array of all currently open file handles. Useful for debugging file handle leaks.

builtins.short_description: Lists files in a ZIP archive
builtins.long_help: Lists all files in a ZIP archive. Optionally filters by path prefix. Returns a JSON array of file entries.

Moves a file from source path to destination path. Can also be used to rename files. Both paths must be within safe
directories.

builtins.short_description: Opens a file and returns a handle
builtins.long_help:
Opens a file for reading or writing and returns a handle string. Mode can be 'r' (read), 'w' (write), or 'a' (append).
Default is 'r'.

builtins.short_description: Opens a ZIP file and returns a handle
builtins.long_help:
Opens a ZIP file for reading or writing. Mode can be 'r' (read) or 'w' (write). Returns a handle for subsequent ZIP
operations.

builtins.short_description: Reads from an open file handle
builtins.long_help: Reads and returns the next chunk of text from an open file handle. Returns empty string at EOF.

builtins.short_description: Reads binary data from file handle
builtins.long_help: Reads binary data from an open file handle and returns it as a byte array.
Reads an entire binary file and returns its contents as a byte array. File must be within a safe directory.

builtins.short_description: Reads a line from file handle
builtins.long_help:
Reads and returns the next line from an open file handle. Optional encoding parameter (default: UTF-8). Returns null at
EOF.
Renames a file to a new name within the same directory. Path is the full file path, newname is just the filename.
Returns the size of a file in bytes. Can accept either a file path or an open file handle.

Extracts files from a ZIP archive to the specified destination directory. Can optionally specify which entries to
extract and whether to overwrite existing files.
Writes text to an open file handle. Does not add a newline automatically.

builtins.short_description: Writes binary data to file handle
builtins.long_help: Writes binary data from a byte array to an open file handle.
Writes binary data from a byte array to a file, overwriting if it exists. File must be within a safe directory.

builtins.short_description: Writes a line to file handle
builtins.long_help: Writes text to an open file handle followed by a newline character.

Appends the specified text content to an existing file. Creates the file if it doesn't exist. The file must be within a
safe directory.

Returns true if the HTTP status code is in the 2xx range (200-299), indicating success. Accepts either a full response
envelope (with 'status' field) or just a status code number.

builtins.short_description: Performs HTTP request with full control
builtins.long_help:
Executes an HTTP request with full control over method, body, headers, and timeout. Returns a JSON envelope containing
status, headers, and body. Method can be GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, etc.

Adds a value to the end of a JSON array at the specified path. Creates the array if it doesn't exist. Returns the
modified JSON object.

Retrieves an array (list) value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns null if the path doesn't exist or
the value is not an array.

Retrieves a double value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns a default value if the path doesn't
exist.

Retrieves an integer value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns a default value if the path doesn't
exist. Alias for json.getInt.
Retrieves a long value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns a default value if the path doesn't exist.

Retrieves an object (map) value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Returns null if the path doesn't exist or
the value is not an object.

Retrieves a value from a JSON object using a dot-notation path. Unlike json.get, this throws an error if the path
doesn't exist, ensuring strict validation.
builtins.example: var value = call json.getStrict(root=config, path="database.host"); // Throws error if path doesn't exist

builtins.long_help: Inserts a value at a specific index in a JSON array at the specified path. Returns the modified JSON object.

Sets a value at the specified path in a JSON object. Unlike json.set, this throws an error if intermediate paths don't
exist, ensuring strict validation. Returns the modified JSON object.
builtins.example:
var data = {"user": {"name": "Alice"}};
var updated = call json.setStrict(root=data, path="user.name", value="Bob");
// Throws error if path doesn't exist

builtins.short_description: Checks if two strings are equal
builtins.long_help: Returns true if the two strings are exactly equal (case-sensitive), false otherwise. Handles null values safely.

Returns true if the two strings are equal ignoring case differences, false otherwise. Useful for case-insensitive
comparisons.
Returns true if the string is null, empty, or contains only whitespace characters, false otherwise.

Returns true if the string is null or has zero length, false otherwise. Unlike isBlank, this does not consider
whitespace.

Executes a system command with optional arguments, timeout, and working directory. Returns a JSON object containing exit
code, stdout, and stderr. Arguments should be provided as a JSON array.

Retrieves a Java system property by name. Returns the property value or a default value if not found. Common properties
include 'user.home', 'os.name', 'java.version', etc.

Returns comprehensive help information about the scripting language, including keywords, operators, datatypes, and all
available builtin functions with their signatures. Outputs to console and returns the text as a string.

Sets a Java system property to the specified value. Pass null as the value to clear the property. Returns the previous
value of the property, or null if it was not set.

Executes a Windows-specific command with optional arguments, timeout, and working directory. Similar to system.command
but optimized for Windows environments. Returns a JSON object containing exit code, stdout, and stderr.

builtins.short_description: Extracts a substring from a string
builtins.long_help:
Extracts a substring from the given string starting at beginIndex. If endIndex is provided, extracts up to (but not
including) that position. If endIndex is omitted, extracts to the end of the string. Uses Java String.substring() semantics.

Returns the index of the first occurrence of searchString within str. If fromIndex is provided, starts searching from
that position. Returns -1 if not found. Uses Java String.indexOf() semantics.

Returns the index of the last occurrence of searchString within str, searching backwards. If fromIndex is provided,
searches backwards from that position. Returns -1 if not found. Uses Java String.lastIndexOf() semantics.

Returns the character at the specified index as a single-character string. Index is zero-based. Throws an error if
index is out of bounds. Uses Java String.charAt() semantics.

Replaces all occurrences of the regex pattern with the replacement string. Supports full Java regular expression syntax.
Use double backslashes for escape sequences. Uses Java String.replaceAll() semantics.

Makes a screen window visible on the display. If no screen name is provided, operates on the current screen context (when
called from within screen event handlers). The screen must have been previously created using the 'screen' statement. Returns
true on success.
builtins.example:
call scr.showScreen(screenName="myScreen");

// Or from within a screen event handler:
call scr.showScreen();

builtins.long_help:
Hides a screen window from the display without closing it. The screen remains in memory and can be shown again using
scr.showScreen. If no screen name is provided, operates on the current screen context (when called from within screen event
handlers). Returns true on success.
builtins.example:
call scr.hideScreen(screenName="myScreen");

// Or from within a screen event handler:
call scr.hideScreen();

builtins.long_help:
Closes a screen window and releases its resources. The screen is removed from memory and any associated event handlers are
terminated. If no screen name is provided, operates on the current screen context (when called from within screen event
handlers). Returns true on success.
builtins.example:
call scr.closeScreen(screenName="myScreen");

// Or from within a screen event handler:
call scr.closeScreen();

builtins.short_description: Sets a property on a screen item
builtins.long_help:
Sets a property value on a specific area item within a screen. The areaItem parameter must be in the format
'screenName.itemName'. Supported properties include 'visible', 'editable', 'disabled', 'colSpan', and 'rowSpan'. Returns true on
success.

builtins.short_description: Gets a property from a screen item
builtins.long_help:
Retrieves a property value from a specific area item within a screen. The areaItem parameter must be in the format
'screenName.itemName'. Returns the current value of the specified property.

builtins.short_description: Gets list of all items in a screen
builtins.long_help:
Returns an array containing the names of all items defined in the specified screen. This includes all fields, buttons, and
other UI elements that are part of the screen's areas.

Returns an array containing information about all items in the specified screen. Similar to scr.getItemList but may include
additional metadata about each item.

builtins.short_description: Sets the status of a screen
builtins.long_help:
Sets the status of a screen to indicate its current state. Valid status values are 'clean' (no changes), 'changed' (has
unsaved changes), or 'error' (contains errors). Returns true on success.

builtins.short_description: Gets the status of a screen
builtins.long_help:
Retrieves the current status of a screen. Returns one of 'clean', 'changed', or 'error' indicating the screen's current
state.

builtins.short_description: Sets an error message for a screen
builtins.long_help:
Sets an error message for a screen and changes its status to 'error'. The error message can be retrieved later using
scr.getError. Returns true on success.

builtins.short_description: Gets the error message for a screen
builtins.long_help: Retrieves the error message associated with a screen. Returns null if no error message has been set.

builtins.short_description: Gets the data source for a screen item
builtins.long_help:
Returns the current data source for a screen item. The source can be either 'data' (uses the data value) or 'display' (uses
the display value).

Left-pads the string with padChar to reach the specified length. If the string is already at or exceeds the desired
length, returns it unchanged. padChar must be a single character.

Right-pads the string with padChar to reach the specified length. If the string is already at or exceeds the desired
length, returns it unchanged. padChar must be a single character.

builtins.short_description: Sets the data source for a screen item
builtins.long_help:
Sets the data source for a screen item. The source parameter must be either 'data' or 'display'. When set to 'data', the
item uses its data value; when set to 'display', it uses its display value. Returns true on success.

builtins.short_description: Gets the status of a screen item
builtins.long_help:
Returns the current status of a screen item. The status indicates whether the item has been modified, has errors, or is in
its original state.

builtins.short_description: Resets a screen item to its original value
builtins.long_help:
Resets a specific screen item back to its original value, discarding any changes made. This is useful for implementing
'undo' functionality for individual fields. Returns true on success.

builtins.short_description: Checks if a screen has unsaved changes
builtins.long_help:
Checks whether any items in the screen have been modified from their original values. Returns true if the screen has
unsaved changes, false otherwise.

builtins.short_description: Checks if a screen has errors
builtins.long_help:
Checks whether the screen has any errors. Returns true if the screen status is 'error' or if an error message has been
set, false otherwise.

builtins.short_description: Reverts all changes in a screen
builtins.long_help:
Reverts all items in the screen back to their original values, discarding all unsaved changes. This is useful for
implementing a 'cancel' or 'reset' function. Returns true on success.

builtins.short_description: Clears all values in a screen
builtins.long_help:
Clears all item values in the screen, setting them to their default empty state. This is different from revert, which
restores original values. Returns true on success.

Disables echo mode which prevents statements from being printed to the console as they are executed. This is useful for
suppressing verbose output during script execution.
builtins.example:
call echo.off();
// Statements will no longer be echoed to console

builtins.long_help:
Enables echo mode which prints statements to the console as they are executed. This is useful for debugging and
understanding script flow. Echo mode can be disabled with echo.off.
builtins.example:
call echo.on();
// Statements will now be echoed to console

builtins.long_help:
Pauses the current script execution for the specified number of milliseconds. This is useful for adding delays between
operations or waiting for external processes. Returns a status string.
builtins.example:
call sleep(millis=1000);
// Pauses for 1 second
print "Resumed after 1 second delay";

builtins.short_description: Loads an external Java class as a plugin
builtins.long_help:
Loads a Java class that implements the EbsFunction interface and registers it with the given alias. The class must be
on the classpath or in a safe directory and have a public no-argument constructor. An optional configuration map can be
passed to initialize the plugin. After loading, call the function using #custom.alias(...) syntax.

Use /help EbsFunction to see the interface overview or /help EbsFunction.java to see the full Java interface code.

parameters.name: config
parameters.description: Optional configuration map passed to initialize(). Example: {"prefix": "[INFO]", "timeout": 30}

builtins.example:
// Load with config
#plugin.load("com.example.MyFunc", "myFunc", {"prefix": "[INFO]", "timeout": 30});

// Call the function
var result = #custom.myFunc("arg1", 42);

builtins.short_description: Calls a loaded custom plugin function
builtins.long_help:
Calls a custom function that was loaded via plugin.load. The alias after 'custom.' must match the alias used when
loading the plugin. Arguments are passed directly to the function's execute() method. Returns the function's result.

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: Arguments to pass to the custom function

builtins.short_description: Checks if a plugin is loaded
builtins.long_help:
Returns true if a plugin with the given alias is currently loaded, false otherwise. Useful for checking before
calling a custom function or for conditional plugin loading.

Unloads a previously loaded plugin and calls its cleanup() method to release resources. Returns true if the plugin
was unloaded, false if it wasn't loaded.

parameters.name: alias
parameters.description: The alias of the plugin to unload

builtins.long_help:
Returns an array of all currently loaded plugin aliases. These aliases can be used with #custom.alias(...) to call
the loaded functions.

builtins.short_description: Gets information about a loaded plugin
builtins.long_help:
Returns a JSON object containing detailed information about a loaded plugin, including its alias, class name, name,
description, and signature metadata (if provided by the plugin via getSignature() or getSignatureString()). Returns null if the plugin is not loaded.

parameters.name: alias
parameters.description: The alias of the plugin to get info for

builtins.short_description: Opens a connection to a mail server
builtins.long_help:
Opens a connection to a mail server using IMAP or POP3 protocol and returns a connection handle for subsequent operations.

Supported protocols: imap, imaps (default, SSL), pop3, pop3s (SSL)

Note: When using Gmail or Google Workspace, you must use an App Password instead of your regular password if 2-Factor Authentication is enabled.

SSL Note: SSL protocols (imaps, pop3s) trust all certificates by default for compatibility.

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: Server port (993 for IMAPS, 143 for IMAP, 995 for POP3S, 110 for POP3)

builtins.long_help:
Lists all available folders in the mail account. Returns a JSON array of folder information including folder name, type, message count and unread count.

Folder types:
messages - folder can contain messages
folders - folder can contain subfolders
messages,folders - folder can contain both
builtins.example:
var folders = call mail.folders(handle);
foreach f in folders {
print f.name + " (" + f.messageCount + " messages)";
}

builtins.long_help:
Lists emails in the specified folder with pagination support. Returns a JSON array of message summaries.

Returned fields:
id - Message number (use with mail.get)
subject - Email subject
from - Sender email address
fromName - Sender display name
date - Sent date as milliseconds since epoch
dateStr - Formatted date string
size - Message size in bytes
read - Boolean indicating if message has been read
builtins.example:
var messages = call mail.list(handle, "INBOX", 1, 10);
foreach msg in messages {
var status = "";
if msg.read == false then { status = "[NEW] "; }
print status + msg.subject + " - " + msg.from;
}

builtins.long_help:
Retrieves the full content of a specific email by its message ID.

Returned fields:
id - Message number
subject - Email subject
from - Array of sender address objects (address, name)
to - Array of recipient addresses
cc - Array of CC addresses
bcc - Array of BCC addresses
date - Sent date as milliseconds
dateStr - Formatted date string
size - Message size in bytes
read - Boolean indicating if read
contentType - MIME content type
body - Email body text (plain or HTML)
attachments - Array of attachment info (filename, contentType, size)
builtins.example:
var email = call mail.get(handle, 1);
print "Subject: " + email.subject;
print "From: " + email.from[0].address;
print "Date: " + email.dateStr;
print email.body;

if email.attachments.length > 0 then {
print "Attachments:";
foreach att in email.attachments {
print " - " + att.filename;
}
}

builtins.long_help: Closes an open mail server connection and releases associated resources. Always call this when done reading emails to properly close the connection.

builtins.short_description: Interface that plugin classes must implement
builtins.long_help:
The EbsFunction interface defines the contract for custom plugin functions. Classes implementing this interface can be
loaded via #plugin.load() and called using #custom.alias(...) syntax.

Required Methods:
String getName() - Returns the display name for logging
String getDescription() - Returns description for help text
Object execute(Object[] args) - Main execution method

Optional Methods (have defaults):
void initialize(Map<String, Object> config) - Called on load with config
void cleanup() - Called on unload for resource cleanup
Map<String, Object> getSignature() - Returns parameter/return type metadata
String getSignatureString() - Returns signature as JSON string

Use /help EbsFunction.java to see the full Java interface code.
builtins.example:
public class MyFunction implements EbsFunction {
public String getName() { return "My Function"; }
public String getDescription() { return "Does something"; }
public Object execute(Object[] args) {
return "Result: " + args[0];
}
}

// Optional: Define signature as JSON string
public String getSignatureString() {
return """
{
"parameters": [
{"name": "input", "type": "string", "required": true, "description": "Input text"},
{"name": "count", "type": "int", "required": false, "description": "Repeat count"}
],
"returnType": "string",
"returnDescription": "Processed output"
}
""";
}

builtins.long_help:
package com.eb.script.interpreter.plugin;

public interface EbsFunction {

// Required methods
String getName();
String getDescription();
Object execute(Object[] args) throws Exception;

// Optional: called on load with config
default void initialize(java.util.Map<String, Object> config) { }

// Optional: called on unload
default void cleanup() { }

// Optional: return signature as Map
default java.util.Map<String, Object> getSignature() { return null; }

// Optional: return signature as JSON string (fallback if getSignature() is null)
default String getSignatureString() { return null; }
}

// Signature JSON structure:
{
"parameters": [
{"name": "param1", "type": "string", "required": true, "description": "First param"},
{"name": "param2", "type": "int", "required": false, "description": "Optional param"}
],
"returnType": "string",
"returnDescription": "What is returned"
}

// Valid types: string, int, long, float, double, bool, json, array, any
builtins.example:
public class EchoFunction implements EbsFunction {

private String prefix = "";

@Override
public String getName() { return "Echo Function"; }

@Override
public String getDescription() { return "Echoes arguments"; }

@Override
public void initialize(Map<String, Object> config) {
if (config != null) {
prefix = (String) config.getOrDefault("prefix", "");
}
}

@Override
public Object execute(Object[] args) {
StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(prefix);
for (Object arg : args) {
sb.append(arg);
}
return sb.toString();
}

@Override
public String getSignatureString() {
return """
{
"parameters": [{"name": "args", "type": "any", "description": "Values to echo"}],
"returnType": "string"
}
""";
}
}
